rules.title: Rules
rules.section:
Credits
Warwick the Kingmaker was designed by Tunc Iper.

Many thanks to Tunc and IZ Games for allowing development of this computer version of his game to be made.

More information on this and other games is available at http://www.izgames.vze.com, including a complete do-it-yourself kit for making your own real-life Warwick the Kingmaker game. At that web site is also a complete rule sheet (with much better pictures than I can draw) from which these rules were taken.

The main board image was drawn by Tunc Iper and permission for use in this game has been granted by him.

The rose picture was developed by Paul Nylander. It was rendered by POV-Ray from source files available at http://www.bugman123.com/Math/Rose.zip

All other graphics drawn by Richard Walter and are put into the public domain.

The program was written by Richard Walter (rwalter42@yahoo.com)

Introduction
Richard Neville, known as "Warwick the Kingmaker", was a leading figure in the Wars of the Roses, during which he helped depose the Lancastrian King Henry VI in favor of the Yorkist King Edward IV. This earned him his nickname of "the Kingmaker" but he later fell out with Edward and restored Henry VI to the throne. During this period Warwick was the richest man in the country outside of the Royal Family and was considered the real ruler of England.

"Kingmaker", while a term originally applied to the activities of Richard Neville, has come to be applied more generally to a person or group that has great influence in a royal or polticial succession, without being a viable candidate. Kingmakers may use political, monetary, religious, and/or military means to interfere in the succession.

Overview
Warwick the Kingmaker is a game for three to five players in which you and your opponents play feuding lords trying to get the most prestigious status in the realm. Since your royal family is not a viable candidate for the throne you must invest your resources to the right candidate for the succession.

The victor is the player with the most prestige points at the end of the game. A player earns prestige points in two ways: by the actions of his own house and by supporting another candidate house. At the beginning of each turn, a player can change the candidate that he supports as he sees fit.

Components
The main board is divided into four sections, labeled 1, 2, 3 and 4.
Each player receives three tokens that will be placed on the board.
Each player also receives a scoring token that is used to keep track of the prestige points gained during the game.

section.title: Playing the Game
section.section:
Playing the Game
The game is divided into turns. The number of turns in a game is equal to the number of players in the game.
Each turn is divided into a single selection phase, followed by three rounds of playing tokens.
After all of the turns in the game are complete, the player with the highest total number of prestige points is the winner.

The Selection Phase
At the beginning of each turn, each player secretly chooses one of the other players to support during this turn. This is the secret support that you provide as the kingmaker. A player may not choose himself for his secret support.

Once all players have selected their player to support, the game enters the placement rounds.

Placement Rounds
Placment rounds begin with the player who is in the seat that corresponds to the turn number. i.e.: On the first turn, the first player will place first. On the second turn, the second player will place first, etc. Thus, each player will have gone first once in each game.

When it is a player's turn in a round, the player must:
   1) Place one of his tokens on the board.
and then
   2) Move any token on the board one quarter clockwise.
Note that any token on the board may be moved clockwise, not just tokens that belong to the player whose turn it is.

Placement and moving continues until all players have placed all three of their tokens on the board. At this point, the board is scored.

Scoring
After all players have placed all of their tokens on the board, each player reveals which other player they chose for their secret support and scoring is done.

Each token on the board is worth the number of points equal to the section of the board on which it is located.
A player's score for his own prestige is the sum of his two highest valued tokens on the board.
A player's score for his supporting prestige is the product of the two highest valued tokens on the board belonging to the player he supported.
A player's total score for a turn is the sum of his own prestige and his supporting prestige.

For example: The Blue player chose to secretly support the Yellow player. At the end of the turn there were blue tokens on the board of value 3, 3 and 4, and yellow tokens on the board of value 1, 2, and 3. The Blue player would score (3+4) = 7 points for his own prestige and would score (2x3) = 6 points for Yellow's prestige. So, Blue would score (7+6) = 13 points for this turn.

After scoring, each player retrieves their tokens from the board and the next turn starts with the players again choosing which other player to secretly support.

End of Game
The game ends after the number of turns equal to the number of players in the game. The winner is the player who has scored the most prestige points during the game.

section.title: Interface Details
section.section:
Main Board
On the left side of the screen is the main board where the tokens will be played.
The top part of the main board is also where the selection of secret support is made during that phase of the game.
The last piece to have been placed on the board will be indicated by a black halo around it.
The last piece to have been moved on the board will be indicated by a white halo around it.

Scoring Track
Running around the board is the scoring track where the scoring tokens for each player indicate the current number of prestige points accumulated by the players. The 0 space is in the upper left corner and points accumulate clockwise around the board.

Anytime during the game, mousing over a scoring marker will display the score received by that player during the most recent turn. Two lines will be drawn that indicate the points scored for the player's own prestige and his supporter's prestige points.

Player Areas
On the right side of the screen are the player areas. Each player area shows the tokens that have not yet been placed on the board and shows a rose which indicates which other player was chosen for secret support.

A player always sees his own player area at the top of the column, with player order going down the screen.

During the selection phase, a player who has not yet chosen another player to secretly support will display a question mark on the selection rose. Once the selection has been made, the icon will change to an exclamation point.

During the selection phase and the rounds, a player will only see his own secret selection, with the other players showing a neutral, gray rose. During scoring, all players will see all of the chosen secret selections.

Choosing Support
During the support selection phase, cards indicating all of the other players in the game will be drawn at the top of the main board. Clicking on one of them will select that player to be supported for the current turn.

Placing Tokens
When it is a player's turn to place a token on the board, mousing over the board will show where the token will be placed. Clicking will place the token on the board.

Moving Tokens
When it is a player's turn to move a token on the board, mousing over a piece on the board will highlight it and draw a line to show where the piece would be moved to. Clicking will slide the token on the board.
